link_counts.title: GitHub - Giro-FRC/AdvantageKitSwerve: AdvantageKitSwerve in off season
What are some ideas software-wise for this off-season?

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: The entire zoning approach seems unnecessary. Each reef face has an April tag that can be converted into a Pose2D object. By using the robot pose function, you can input a list of reef poses from these April tags, and it will return the closest one.
Thank you very much for your suggestion. I didn’t know that, I can update the project in a free time.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked:
You can obtain a list of positions for the reef poles (or the specific points required to score at each reef pole) by applying two different transformations to each AprilTag. After performing these transformations, you can then use the same `nearest` method as before to identify the closest points.

We achieve this by:

1. Applying the AprilTag_LEFT_TRANSFORM to each pose and adding the resulting position to the list of reef pole locations.
2. Similarly, apply the AprilTag_RIGHT_TRANSFORM to each pose and add the outcome to the list of reef pole locations.

This process ensures we accurately map each pose to its corresponding reef pole location.

We appreciate your suggestion. Unfortunately, due to the creation of an elevator this year, we were only able to implement the coral adjustment in the L1 system. Without access to a functional elevator for testing, adjustments were made based on the L1 system instead.

posts.name: Val DiBona
posts.cooked: We did something similar at runtime by aligning to the closest tag of the target location for automatic alignment. This method provides a clear diagram of the regions involved. From there, we add an offset to specify whether we want alignment to the left, right, or middle of the reef's edge, using an enum with corresponding transformation values.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: It’s still helpful to place the coral under the branch so that you can fit two side by side.
You are very right, I had never thought of this code because we could not test it outside the simulation. Thanks again for your help.
Is there any way to see these fields on advantagescope? Was your team able to achieve this?

posts.name: Val DiBona
posts.cooked: I’ll be honest, I was using Desmos for the graph. Not really? I remember another team coded something called 'region2d' and potentially made it loggable.
I came across something interesting from the Golden Horn Team’s behind-the-bumper video. You can see it at the 4:37-minute mark. I’d be happy to collaborate on this topic if you’re open to it.

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked:
We implemented a system in 2025 to model regions of the field as polygons using Java code. The PolygonRegion class represents a region defined by its vertices and includes methods for creating and managing these shapes. This class builds upon work from another team (credit to FRC-3061) and uses libraries like Translation2d and StructArrayPublisher for functionality. We utilized this implementation in our mainbot project, logging polygon points to Network Table for visualization in AdvantageScope. 

We also explored using zones for advanced context switching during autonomous operations, relying on AllianceFlipUtil to adjust scoring actions based on the field layout. While this approach involved more complexity than needed, it provided an interesting discussion point with judges and allowed for versatile scoring strategies during matches.
Thank you for being an inspiration for this project. While I’ve reviewed your code, I’m still unsure how you redirect these fields to advantagescope. I’d be very grateful for your assistance.

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked: We use a StructArrayPublisher. A simple example using poses is available on the AdvantageScope documentation page. Our implementation is just as simple. We define the region via an array of Translation2ds in the Region constructor. In mainbot-2025's PolygonRegion.java, lines 30-33 set up the struct array publisher similarly to the AdvantageScope example but use Translation2d instead of Pose2d. Then, we call logPoints, a custom method that sends a value to the previously defined publisher. This value is the Translation2d array provided in the class constructor.

posts.name: Cole Hunt
Dan
posts.cooked: You can use the Field2D object to support arbitrary objects via `field.getObject("name")`. Our testing involved simulating the chassis, grabbing the nearest tag, setting a pose for it on a field, generating appropriate transforms, and adding them to the field. This was repeated for any other items of interest. To create lines, you can use the `.setPoses(....)` method, which allows you to adjust display styles on the dashboard. On Glass devices, there are several display options for creating useful visualizations. Specifically, we tested the functionality using field trajectories and explored additional features, such as setting a specific object name to an image.

Thank you very much for your help. I finally managed to add these lines with the help of ChatGPT. I pushed the new code to the repo; you can check it if you want.

But the comment lines are written in Turkish for my team to understand for now. Soon, I will translate all these lines into English. I would appreciate it if you could ignore this for now.

user.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
